Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

In Scenario <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, a copper sphere with specific heat <math alttext="Lowercase c sub uppercase C u equals, 386 joules per kilogram degree Celsius" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>c</mi> <mtext>Cu</mtext> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <mn>386</mn> <mspace width="0.2em"> </mspace> <mfrac> <mtext>J</mtext> <mrow> <mtext>kg</mtext> <mo>⋅</mo> <mo>°</mo> <mtext>C</mtext> </mrow> </mfrac> </math> and total mass of <math alttext="400 grams" overflow="scroll"><mn>400</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> has been submerged in liquid nitrogen with a temperature of <math alttext="negative 180 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>180</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></mpadded><mo rspace="0em">°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> for a long time. When the sphere is removed, it is then immediately transferred to an insulated aluminum container of mass <math alttext="500 grams" overflow="scroll"><mn>500</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> and specific heat <math alttext="c sub A I equals, 900 joules per kilogram degree Celsius" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>c</mi><mtext>Al</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>900</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mfrac><mtext>J</mtext><mrow><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mfrac></math>. The container has been filled with <math alttext="900 grams" overflow="scroll"><mn>900</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> of water for a long time. The temperature of the water and the aluminum container is <math alttext="10 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mo rspace="0em">°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>. The specific heat of water is <math alttext="C sub water equals, 4,186 joules per kilogram degree Celsius" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>c</mi><mtext>water</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>4186</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mfrac><mtext>J</mtext><mrow><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mfrac></math>.
content.question: (a) Calculate the final temperature of the system consisting of the water, copper sphere, and the insulated aluminum container after they have reached thermal equilibrium. Begin your calculation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

frqParts.text: (a) Calculate the final temperature of the system consisting of the water, copper sphere, and the insulated aluminum container after they have reached thermal equilibrium. Begin your calculation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

The insulation from the aluminum container is now removed. The temperature of the air in the room is greater than the final equilibrium temperature of the copper, water, and aluminum container.
(b) On the axes in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, sketch a graph of the rate of energy transfer <math alttext="the fraction Q over delta lowercase t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>Q</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></math> as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> through the walls of the aluminum container. A positive rate of energy transfer represents energy moving from the interior to the exterior of the aluminum container and a negative rate of energy transfer represents energy moving from the exterior to the interior of the aluminum container.

In Scenario <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, the entire process of Scenario <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is repeated, with only the following changes:

The aluminum container is filled with more water than Scenario <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>.

The insulation has been removed from the aluminum container.
(c) Indicate whether the final temperature of the system consisting of the water, copper sphere, and aluminum container after they have reached thermal equilibrium will be greater than, less than or equal to the temperature calculated in part (a). Justify your answer by giving two reasons for the difference in final temperature.

skill.text: 1.C: Create qualitative sketches of graphs that represent features of a model or the behavior of a physical system.
